Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with crude representation of winged sphinx walking to right; motif stamped; pierced through diameter; light blue greenish glaze relatively well-preserved; yellowish core.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs and scaraboids with a winged sphinx motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). A number of different versions are illustrated in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 28-30 and Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 62. This type was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A108-113, see especially A109 for this piece). Gordon misidentified this scaraboid with Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 25, but the latter depicts a walking winged lion and corresponds to BM 1886,0401.1616. For a very close design on a scaraboid from Naukratis, see Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1888.210. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 97, type XXVIII A109)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.008) (phase 3)
